SP.UWT.TFRT.Q3.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SP.UWT.TFRT.Q3.ZS.name: Unmet need for family planning (total) (% of married women): Q3
SP.UWT.TFRT.Q3.ZS.sourceNote: Unmet need for family planning: Percentage of currently married women with unmet need for family planning for spacing, for limiting, and the sum of these two (total). Unmet need for spacing includes pregnant women whose pregnancy was mistimed, amenorrheic women who are not using family planning and whose last birth was mistimed, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and say they want to wait 2 or more years for their next birth. Also included in unmet need for spacing are fecund women who are not using any method of family planning and say they are unsure whether they want another child or who want another child but are unsure when to have the birth unless they say it would not be a problem if they discovered they were pregnant in the next few weeks. Unmet need for limiting refers to pregnant women whose pregnancy was unwanted, amenorrheic women whose last child was unwanted, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and who want no more children. Excluded from the unmet need category are pregnant and amenorrheic women who became pregnant while using a method (these women are in need of a better method of contraception).

SP.UWT.TFRT.Q4.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SP.UWT.TFRT.Q4.ZS.name: Unmet need for family planning (total) (% of married women): Q4
SP.UWT.TFRT.Q4.ZS.sourceNote: Unmet need for family planning: Percentage of currently married women with unmet need for family planning for spacing, for limiting, and the sum of these two (total). Unmet need for spacing includes pregnant women whose pregnancy was mistimed, amenorrheic women who are not using family planning and whose last birth was mistimed, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and say they want to wait 2 or more years for their next birth. Also included in unmet need for spacing are fecund women who are not using any method of family planning and say they are unsure whether they want another child or who want another child but are unsure when to have the birth unless they say it would not be a problem if they discovered they were pregnant in the next few weeks. Unmet need for limiting refers to pregnant women whose pregnancy was unwanted, amenorrheic women whose last child was unwanted, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and who want no more children. Excluded from the unmet need category are pregnant and amenorrheic women who became pregnant while using a method (these women are in need of a better method of contraception).

SH.STA.STN3.Q1.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.STA.STN3.Q1.ZS.name: Malnourished children (stunting, -3SD) (% of children under 5): Q1 (lowest)
SH.STA.STN3.Q1.ZS.sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). Each index is expressed in terms of the number of standard deviation (SD) units from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.

SH.FPL.KWMD.Q2.ZS.sourceNote: Knowledge of contraception: Percentage of currently married women who know at least one contraceptive method and at least one modern contraceptive method.

SP.UWT.SPCG.Q5.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SP.UWT.SPCG.Q5.ZS.name: Unmet need for family planning (for spacing) (% of married women): Q5 (highest)
SP.UWT.SPCG.Q5.ZS.sourceNote: Unmet need for family planning: Percentage of currently married women with unmet need for family planning for spacing, for limiting, and the sum of these two (total). Unmet need for spacing includes pregnant women whose pregnancy was mistimed, amenorrheic women who are not using family planning and whose last birth was mistimed, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and say they want to wait 2 or more years for their next birth. Also included in unmet need for spacing are fecund women who are not using any method of family planning and say they are unsure whether they want another child or who want another child but are unsure when to have the birth unless they say it would not be a problem if they discovered they were pregnant in the next few weeks. Unmet need for limiting refers to pregnant women whose pregnancy was unwanted, amenorrheic women whose last child was unwanted, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and who want no more children. Excluded from the unmet need category are pregnant and amenorrheic women who became pregnant while using a method (these women are in need of a better method of contraception).

SH.MLR.PREG.Q4.ZS.sourceNote: Anti-malarial drug use by pregnant women: Percentage of women with a live birth in the two years preceding the survey who during the pregnancy took any antimalarial drug for prevention, and who took SP/Fansidar two or more doses.

Unmet need for spacing includes pregnant women whose pregnancy was mistimed, amenorrheic women who are not using family planning and whose last birth was mistimed, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and say they want to wait 2 or more years for their next birth. Also included in unmet need for spacing are fecund women who are not using any method of family planning and say they are unsure whether they want another child or who want another child but are unsure when to have the birth unless they say it would not be a problem if they discovered they were pregnant in the next few weeks. Unmet need for limiting refers to pregnant women whose pregnancy was unwanted, amenorrheic women whose last child was unwanted, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and who want no more children. Excluded from the unmet need category are pregnant and amenorrheic women who became pregnant while using a method (these women are in need of a better method of contraception).

SH.IMM.MEAS.Q1.ZS.name: Vaccinations (Measles) (% of children ages 12-23 months): Q1 (lowest)
SH.IMM.MEAS.Q1.ZS.sourceNote: Vaccinations: Percentage of children 12-23 months who have received specific vaccines by the time of the survey (according to the vaccination card or the mother's report). Children with all vaccinations refer children who have received BCG, measles, and three doses each of DPT and polio vaccine (excluding polio 0). Some MICS surveys refer children in different age groups (e.g. 18-29 months, or 15-26 months).

SH.STA.MLN3.Q2.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.STA.MLN3.Q2.ZS.name: Malnourished children (underweight, -3SD) (% of children under 5): Q2
SH.STA.MLN3.Q2.ZS.sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). Each index is expressed in terms of the number of standard deviation (SD) units from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.

The types of problem specified are; knowing where to go for treatment, getting permission to go for treatment, getting money for treatment, distance to health facility, having to take transport, not wanting to go alone, and concern there may not be a female provider.

If the respondent mentioned more than one provider, only the most qualified provider is considered. The DHS surveys refer births in the three years preceding the survey, the MICS2 surveys refer births in the one year preceding the survey, and the MICS3 surveys refer births in the two years preceding the survey.

SH.IMM.MEAS.Q4.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile

SH.IMM.MEAS.Q4.ZS.sourceNote: Vaccinations: Percentage of children 12-23 months who have received specific vaccines by the time of the survey (according to the vaccination card or the mother's report). Children with all vaccinations refer children who have received BCG, measles, and three doses each of DPT and polio vaccine (excluding polio 0). Some MICS surveys refer children in different age groups (e.g. 18-29 months, or 15-26 months).

SH.STA.MALN.Q5.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.STA.MALN.Q5.ZS.name: Malnourished children (underweight, -2SD) (% of children under 5): Q5 (highest)
SH.STA.MALN.Q5.ZS.sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). Each index is expressed in terms of the number of standard deviation (SD) units from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.

SP.UWT.LMTG.Q1.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SP.UWT.LMTG.Q1.ZS.name: Unmet need for family planning (for limiting) (% of married women): Q1 (lowest)
SP.UWT.LMTG.Q1.ZS.sourceNote: Unmet need for family planning: Percentage of currently married women with unmet need for family planning for spacing, for limiting, and the sum of these two (total). Unmet need for spacing includes pregnant women whose pregnancy was mistimed, amenorrheic women who are not using family planning and whose last birth was mistimed, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and say they want to wait 2 or more years for their next birth. Also included in unmet need for spacing are fecund women who are not using any method of family planning and say they are unsure whether they want another child or who want another child but are unsure when to have the birth unless they say it would not be a problem if they discovered they were pregnant in the next few weeks. Unmet need for limiting refers to pregnant women whose pregnancy was unwanted, amenorrheic women whose last child was unwanted, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and who want no more children. Excluded from the unmet need category are pregnant and amenorrheic women who became pregnant while using a method (these women are in need of a better method of contraception).

Unmet need for spacing includes pregnant women whose pregnancy was mistimed, amenorrheic women who are not using family planning and whose last birth was mistimed, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and say they want to wait 2 or more years for their next birth. Unmet need for limiting refers to pregnant women whose pregnancy was unwanted, amenorrheic women whose last child was unwanted, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and who want no more children. Excluded from the unmet need category are pregnant and amenorrheic women who became pregnant while using a method (these women are in need of a better method of contraception).

SH.STA.ORHF.Q3.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.STA.ORHF.Q3.ZS.name: Treatment of diarrhea (ORS, RHS or increased fluids) (% of children under 5): Q3
SH.STA.ORHF.Q3.ZS.sourceNote: Treatment of diarrhea (ORS, RHS or increased fluids): Percentage of children under age five years with diarrhea in the two weeks preceding the survey who received oral rehydration solution (ORS), recommended home solution (RHS) or increased fluids.

SH.MLR.NETH.Q3.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.MLR.NETH.Q3.ZS.name: Household posession of mosquito nets (any type of mosquito net) (% of households): Q3

SP.UWT.SPCG.Q4.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SP.UWT.SPCG.Q4.ZS.name: Unmet need for family planning (for spacing) (% of married women): Q4
SP.UWT.SPCG.Q4.ZS.sourceNote: Unmet need for family planning: Percentage of currently married women with unmet need for family planning for spacing, for limiting, and the sum of these two (total). Unmet need for spacing includes pregnant women whose pregnancy was mistimed, amenorrheic women who are not using family planning and whose last birth was mistimed, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and say they want to wait 2 or more years for their next birth. Also included in unmet need for spacing are fecund women who are not using any method of family planning and say they are unsure whether they want another child or who want another child but are unsure when to have the birth unless they say it would not be a problem if they discovered they were pregnant in the next few weeks. Unmet need for limiting refers to pregnant women whose pregnancy was unwanted, amenorrheic women whose last child was unwanted, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and who want no more children. Excluded from the unmet need category are pregnant and amenorrheic women who became pregnant while using a method (these women are in need of a better method of contraception).

SH.FPL.KWMD.Q5.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.FPL.KWMD.Q5.ZS.name: Knowledge of contraception (modern method) (% of married women): Q5 (highest)
SH.FPL.KWMD.Q5.ZS.sourceNote: Knowledge of contraception: Percentage of currently married women who know at least one contraceptive method and at least one modern contraceptive method.

SH.STA.BRTC.Q1.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.STA.BRTC.Q1.ZS.name: Assistance during delivery (any skilled personnel) (% of births): Q1 (lowest)
SH.STA.BRTC.Q1.ZS.sourceNote: Assistance during delivery (Assisted births): Percentage of live births in the three (one, two) years preceding the survey attended by any skilled personnel and by a doctor.  The DHS surveys refer births in the three years preceding the survey, the MICS2 surveys refer births in the one year preceding the survey, and the MICS3 surveys refer births in the two years preceding the survey.

SH.ACS.NOFP.Q2.ZS.sourceNote: Problems in accessing health care: Percentage of women who report they have big problems in accessing health care for themselves when they are sick, by type of problem. SH.STA.ANVC.Q2.ZS.sourceNote: Antenatal care: Percentage of women with one or more live births in the three (one, two) years preceding the survey who have received at least one antenatal care during pregnancy before the most recent birth from any skilled personnel and from a doctor. If the respondent mentioned more than one provider, only the most qualified provider is considered. The DHS surveys refer births in the three years preceding the survey, the MICS2 surveys refer births in the one year preceding the survey, and the MICS3 surveys refer births in the two years preceding the survey.

SH.STA.BRTP.Q3.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.STA.BRTP.Q3.ZS.name: Assistance during delivery (doctor) (% of births): Q3
SH.STA.BRTP.Q3.ZS.sourceNote: Assistance during delivery (Assisted births): Percentage of live births in the three (one, two) years preceding the survey attended by any skilled personnel and by a doctor.  The DHS surveys refer births in the three years preceding the survey, the MICS2 surveys refer births in the one year preceding the survey, and the MICS3 surveys refer births in the two years preceding the survey.

SH.IMM.ALLV.Q5.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.IMM.ALLV.Q5.ZS.name: Vaccinations (all vaccinations) (% of children ages 12-23 months): Q5 (highest)
SH.IMM.ALLV.Q5.ZS.sourceNote: Vaccinations: Percentage of children 12-23 months who have received specific vaccines by the time of the survey (according to the vaccination card or the mother's report). Children with all vaccinations refer children who have received BCG, measles, and three doses each of DPT and polio vaccine (excluding polio 0). Some MICS surveys refer children in different age groups (e.g. 18-29 months, or 15-26 months).

SP.MTR.1519.Q3.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SP.MTR.1519.Q3.ZS.name: Teenage pregnancy and motherhood (% of women ages 15-19 who have had children or are currently pregnant): Q3
SP.MTR.1519.Q3.ZS.sourceNote: Teenage pregnancy and motherhood: Percentage of women aged 15-19 years who are mothers or pregnant with their first child.

SP.UWT.LMTG.Q5.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SP.UWT.LMTG.Q5.ZS.name: Unmet need for family planning (for limiting) (% of married women): Q5 (highest)
SP.UWT.LMTG.Q5.ZS.sourceNote: Unmet need for family planning: Percentage of currently married women with unmet need for family planning for spacing, for limiting, and the sum of these two (total). Unmet need for spacing includes pregnant women whose pregnancy was mistimed, amenorrheic women who are not using family planning and whose last birth was mistimed, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and say they want to wait 2 or more years for their next birth. Also included in unmet need for spacing are fecund women who are not using any method of family planning and say they are unsure whether they want another child or who want another child but are unsure when to have the birth unless they say it would not be a problem if they discovered they were pregnant in the next few weeks. Unmet need for limiting refers to pregnant women whose pregnancy was unwanted, amenorrheic women whose last child was unwanted, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and who want no more children. Excluded from the unmet need category are pregnant and amenorrheic women who became pregnant while using a method (these women are in need of a better method of contraception).

SH.IMM.IDPT.Q5.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.IMM.IDPT.Q5.ZS.name: Vaccinations (DPT 3) (% of children ages 12-23 months): Q5 (highest)

SH.ACS.ALON.Q2.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.ACS.ALON.Q2.ZS.name: Problems in accessing health care (not wanting to go alone) (% of women): Q2
SH.ACS.ALON.Q2.ZS.sourceNote: Problems in accessing health care: Percentage of women who report they have big problems in accessing health care for themselves when they are sick, by type of problem. SH.STA.STNT.Q5.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.STA.STNT.Q5.ZS.name: Malnourished children (stunting, -2SD) (% of children under 5): Q5 (highest)
SH.STA.STNT.Q5.ZS.sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). Each index is expressed in terms of the number of standard deviation (SD) units from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.

SP.UWT.SPCG.Q1.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SP.UWT.SPCG.Q1.ZS.name: Unmet need for family planning (for spacing) (% of married women): Q1 (lowest)
SP.UWT.SPCG.Q1.ZS.sourceNote: Unmet need for family planning: Percentage of currently married women with unmet need for family planning for spacing, for limiting, and the sum of these two (total). Unmet need for spacing includes pregnant women whose pregnancy was mistimed, amenorrheic women who are not using family planning and whose last birth was mistimed, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and say they want to wait 2 or more years for their next birth. Also included in unmet need for spacing are fecund women who are not using any method of family planning and say they are unsure whether they want another child or who want another child but are unsure when to have the birth unless they say it would not be a problem if they discovered they were pregnant in the next few weeks. Unmet need for limiting refers to pregnant women whose pregnancy was unwanted, amenorrheic women whose last child was unwanted, and fecund women who are neither pregnant nor amenorrheic and who are not using any method of family planning and who want no more children. Excluded from the unmet need category are pregnant and amenorrheic women who became pregnant while using a method (these women are in need of a better method of contraception).

SH.STA.WAST.Q4.ZS.source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
SH.STA.WAST.Q4.ZS.name: Malnourished children (wasting, -2SD) (% of children under 5): Q4
SH.STA.WAST.Q4.ZS.sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). Each index is expressed in terms of the number of standard deviation (SD) units from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.
